sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Qāf

item.label: q --˃ /g/ + affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) ǵ
q --˃ /g/ + affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) ǧ

wib:featureValueObservation.note: "All Muslim men and majority of Christian men used ḳ"
"Out of thirteen Muslim women ten used ḳ"

"The most hamza speakers are women which can be associated with prestige. In this dialectal area hamza is reported to be a characteristic feature of urban pronunciation and, moreover, concerning the gender distinction it is attributed mostly to women"
"Out of the twelve Christian women only two pronounced ḳ instead of ʔ
Extinct feature

"The existence of g, voiced reflex of qāf in fellāḥi dialects is reported not only with general indication of our area, but with specific mention of Yāfa, near Nazareth. This information is verified by the recording of a very old Christian female informant of that village"

Devoicing of /g/ when before /t/- ex. ktirab «he approached». The root g-t-l «to kill» is realized k-t-l. Uvular realisation is preserved in MSA loanwords, ex. qaṛṛaṛaw «they decided», b-qiyādǝt «led by», sābiqan «previously»
CHECK EXAMPLES IN RECORDINGS
Lexicalized use of k. ex. katla
Young speakers often use q in words realized with /g/ or /ǧ/ by older speakers, ex. gidīm or ǧidim - qadīm «old», gilīl or ǧilīl - qalīl «few, little»
Uvular realisation is preserved in MSA loanwords, ex. taqrīban «approximately», qarīban «soon» and in some Turkish loanwords, ex. qawūn «melon»
With the exception of druze speakers residents in Beirut who traditionally realize it as q
Lexicalized occassional use of q and k: ex. qanīna (bottle) and k in wakt (time)
vestigial variants of q>ǧ: ʕeǧib "young children", ǧiddāmi "in front of me", ǧider "cauldron"
in the contiguity of front vowels g can but need not to be realized as affricate ǵ [dz]
Irbid is populated by 3 regional groups: Urbanites who haveʔ, Rurals who present k, and Ḥōrānis who display g.
Irbid is populated by 3 regional groups: Urbanites who haveʔ, Rurals who present k, and Ḥōrānis who display g.
Irbid is populated by 3 regional groups: Urbanites who haveʔ, Rurals who present k, and Ḥōrānis who display g.
Irbid is populated by 3 regional groups: Urbanites who haveʔ, Rurals who present k, and Ḥōrānis who display g.
example taken from texts in the article
q_q in vicinity of voiceless consonants with root *w - q- t
q_k in vicinity of voiceless consonants with root *q-t-l
Velarisation of g occurrs in emphatic environment: gaḏ̣a "judging", gamar "moon
q_k in vicinity of voiceless consonants + root *qtl and *qtr
occurs in front vowel environments
occurs in Persian borrowings that have a cognate lexeme in Persian or loans from MSA
limited to a very small number of items
if it is word final or before a consonant q can freely alternate with x
in contact position before the voiced bilabial ploive /b/
In azZaʔaziʔ "Zaqāziq (name of a town in the eastern Delta)" *q had a ʔ reflex and a k reflex in katal "he killed".

"In loans from CA one may also hear q for *q, eg qabīlitna ""our tribe"", ḥuquq ""rights"", muṯaqqafīn ""educated people"", or ḳ as in aḳall ""less"". In katal, yuktul""beat; kill"" *q has a k reflex, as well as in kinābil alhawn ""mortar shells"" (recorded in RA) . Notice that in the instance of katal, yuktul a back-formation of the devoiced g under the influence of voiceless t in the imperfect, i.e. regressive partial assimilation in *yugtul (pronounced[' yuktul ]), appears to plausibly account for the presence of voiceless k throughout the conjugation. "
MSA loandwords are exceptions.
MSA loanwords are exceptions.
In a loan from MSA q was a reflex for *q, e.g.: qiṭār izzuwāǧ "the marriage train", and in an imitation of CaA a speaker had ʔ for *q: ʔāʕid "sitting".

"In loans from CA one may also hear q for *q, eg qabīlitna ""our tribe"", ḥuquq ""rights"", muṯaqqafīn ""educated people"", or ḳ as in aḳall ""less"". In katal, yuktul""beat; kill"" *q has a k reflex, as well as in kinābil alhawn ""mortar shells"" (recorded in RA) . Notice that in the instance of katal, yuktul a back-formation of the devoiced g under the influence of voiceless t in the imperfect, i.e. regressive partial assimilation in *yugtul (pronounced[' yuktul ]), appears to plausibly account for the presence of voiceless k throughout the conjugation. "
MSA loandwords are exceptions.

"In loans from CA one may also hear q for *q, eg qabīlitna ""our tribe"", ḥuquq ""rights"", muṯaqqafīn ""educated people"", or ḳ as in aḳall ""less"". In katal, yuktul""beat; kill"" *q has a k reflex, as well as in kinābil alhawn ""mortar shells"" (recorded in RA) . Notice that in the instance of katal, yuktul a back-formation of the devoiced g under the influence of voiceless t in the imperfect, i.e. regressive partial assimilation in *yugtul (pronounced[' yuktul ]), appears to plausibly account for the presence of voiceless k throughout the conjugation. "
MSA loandwords are exceptions.
In azZaʔaziʔ "Zaqāziq (name of a town in the eastern Delta)" *q had a ʔ reflex and a k reflex in katal "he killed".

"In loans from CA one may also hear q for *q, eg qabīlitna ""our tribe"", ḥuquq ""rights"", muṯaqqafīn ""educated people"", or ḳ as in aḳall ""less"". In katal, yuktul""beat; kill"" *q has a k reflex, as well as in kinābil alhawn ""mortar shells"" (recorded in RA) . Notice that in the instance of katal, yuktul a back-formation of the devoiced g under the influence of voiceless t in the imperfect, i.e. regressive partial assimilation in *yugtul (pronounced[' yuktul ]), appears to plausibly account for the presence of voiceless k throughout the conjugation. "
MSA loandwords are exceptions.
MSA loanwords are exceptions.
Women always use hamza while male informants show a somewhat variable and inconstant representation, sometimes hamza, sometimes k or ḳ, and sometimes even the preservation of the rural q.
Women always use hamza while male informants show a somewhat variable and inconstant representation, sometimes hamza, sometimes k or ḳ, and sometimes even the preservation of the rural q.
Women always use hamza while male informants show a somewhat variable and inconstant representation, sometimes hamza, sometimes k or ḳ, and sometimes even the preservation of the rural q.
Women always use hamza while male informants show a somewhat variable and inconstant representation, sometimes hamza, sometimes k or ḳ, and sometimes even the preservation of the rural q.

q is frequently pronounced as unvoiced k in the word wakit ("time"), probably through assimilation to the following unvoiced consonant t. It is occasionally pronounced as ġ in words derived from the Old Arabic root q-d-r, e.g. niġdar ("we can").
g is the rarest realization of q.
It is a velarized g.
Women use a glottal stop more frequently than men.
Women use a glottal stop more frequently than men.
with loanwords from MSA q is used, loanwords from fellahi/rural dialects use g
It is usual that the same speaker deliberately interchanges q, k and ġ.
In some cases it can also be realized as q (qárya (village)), k (táktaʿ (you cut)) or even ' (Hamza), as in ta'ālīd (traditions).
the source does not provide a translation. It probably means 'he sleeps', 'he lies down' or similar.
sometimes q > qʔ (glottalization) but not subject to any specific conditions
q > g, mostly regarding lexic that is related to rural life
Both /g/ and /q/ are productive and may be used for the same word e.g. gəlb and qəlb both refer to heart
/q/ is still heard in certain words, qām ‘he woke up’
Lexic regarding religion and the city: q=q, in rare cases q>k wakt 'time'

"Nevertheless, there are numerous examples where a voiceless realization /q/ has been preserved, e.g.: qahwatun > qăhwa „coffee‟, qāsa > qās „he threw‟, ṯaqīlun > tqīl „heavy‟, laqītu > lqīt „I found‟, muqallaqun > mqăllăq „hurried‟. CA /q/ is realized as /k/ in the following words: *ḏā-l-waqt > dăṛwăk „now‟, CA qatala > ktəl „he killed‟. "
the reflex of /q/ as /k/ is very rare, the most striking example is ktel for qatala 'he killed'
the reflex of /q/ as /k/ is very rare, the most striking example is ktel for qatala 'he killed'
The /q/ and the /g/ are used to differentiate between different words e.g. bégra - cow but bágra - the second sūra of the Qur’ān
Whilst /g/ prevails more than /q/ as a reflex of MSA /q/, there are many instances where /q/ is also retained, e.g. qlāṣt (socks)
We may also find a series of minimal pairs based on the opposition /q/ 􀂏 /g/: qəṛʕa bottle is not gərʕa pumkin
We may also find a series of minimal pairs based on the opposition /q/ 􀂏 /g/: qəṛʕa bottle is not gərʕa pumkin
/q/ could be reflected as /g/ in certain words e.g. gidem 'he bit'

In some areas, the forms /g/ and /q/ co-exist, with /g/ having a pejorative meaning ; this co-existance can also see two reflections of the same word - one refering to the abstract meaning and one to the concrete meaning of the word
q and g are phonemes, they are lexicalized, ʕalag typical bedouin, original meaning "to hang"
q and g are phonemes, they are lexicalized, ʕalag typical bedouin, original meaning "to hang"
g is receding
ʔ sometimes used in loanwords from Cairo such as birtuʔān "oranges"
ġ is used with some roots, especialle qdr: ġādir "able", yiġdaṛ "he can"; but also other words: ġalbih "his heart", yiġiṣṣílhum "he informed them"
for MSA words q is usually used, sometimes ḳ: iḳtiṣadiyya "economically"
more frequently used than /q/
less frequently used than /g/, except for MSA
The /q/ is fronted in /k/ in sedentary rural variants: fōq> fōk , “above”
in some lexemes including loanwords /g/ can be interchanged with /k/
q-ġ-x in complementary distribution
q-ġ-x in complementary distribution
q-ġ-x in complementary distribution
